newsitem.title: DUBAI: U.S. and Turkish firms load Iraqi oil.
newsitem.headline: U.S. and Turkish firms load Iraqi oil.

text.p: Iraq is loading crude tankers chartered by Turkish refiner TUPRAS at Ceyhan and by U.S. firms Coastal and independent Bayoil at Mina al Bakr in the northern Gulf, industry sources said on Monday.

The first tanker to export Iraqi oil since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990 is expected to be by TUPRAS using the tanker Gole under a 75,000 barrels per day (bpd) contract signed with Iraq's State Oil Marketing Organisation (SOMO).
Turkish pipeline officials on Monday said that the loading of the tanker carrying Kirkuk crude was nearly completed.
Coastal Corp currently has the 274,585 deadweight tonne Star of Africa tanker loading Basrah crude at the Mina al-Bakr export terminal, 12 miles (19 km) off the southern Fao Peninsula.
The 272,000 deadweight tonne Leonidas VLCC docked at al-Bakr late on Sunday and is now being loaded, shipping sources said.
The Leonidas has been chartered by U.S. firm Bayoil, trade sources said.
Iraqi Oil Minister Amir Muhammad Rasheed on Sunday said that the Star of Africa would leave within 48 hours.
Gulf shipping sources on Monday said that the vessel was being loaded slowly and that it could take some four days to load a a full two million barrels onto the Star of Africa VLCC.
"It is very slow loading rate. They don't want to put pressure on the pipelines," a Gulf shipping source said.
Coastal earlier this year sought to take Iraqi crude to its refinery on the Caribbean island of Aruba.
Under an "oil-for-food" deal agreed between Baghdad and the United Nations, Iraq will export between 500,000 barrels per day (bpd) and 600,000 bpd of its crude at current prices.
